Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Cloud Based Laboratory for Remote Experiential Learning in Robotics
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to enable students and trainees to take state-of-the-art robotics laboratory classes from anywhere in the world. The proposed learning system is aimed to be incorporated as online courses, with the potential of being attended by more than a million students. The addressable market represents hundreds of millions of dollars considering online courses, secondary schools and industrial training. Laboratory courses in colleges and high schools require students to be physically present next to the equipment. With the proposed remote robotics laboratory, students and trainees can take laboratory classes just turning on their mobile devices or computers. Most importantly, the students can conduct the laboratory tutorials anywhere across the globe and at any time. This technology can be transformative for accessing expensive laboratory equipment not present in many institutions or companies. The system we provide consists of a robotic device currently being used inside NASA robots. Therefore, students using the remote laboratory will learn the use of real-world, state-of-the-art equipment that can be highly valuable for their job careers in STEM fields.

The proposed project will solve two key problems in online learning. First, no known commercially available laboratory online course exists that provides students remote hands-on experimentation. The second is that the same content is delivered to all students regardless of their current understanding level. Distributed communications, robotic software and web framework technologies will be integrated to provide access to state-of-the-art laboratory equipment. The second key innovation is the delivery of content adaptively tailored to individual needs. The innovation, consists of three key components. A web framework that connects equipment to servers and personal mobile devices, an intelligent content tutoring system, scheduling usage times and student evaluation regarding skill acquisition and assessments. The team anticipates that being remotely located will be slightly less effective than being next to the equipment but superior than learning theory only.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The NSF Phase I SBIR grant supported us in the research and development of the base technology required to provide 24x7 access to state-of-the-art robotics hardware in real-time to anyone with an internet connection, anywhere in the world. As a result of this project, we were able to develop a prototype that has been accessed hundreds of times from locations across the US during the course of this project with no run-time failures. We were able to conduct controlled tests with students at two educational institutions to demonstrate efficacy and interest, but also identified challenges with large scale implementation of this technology for the education space. Additionally, we made in-roads into intelligent assessment which is a critical component to making this technology be more similar to classroom teaching. The project also helped us understand the diversity of the education market, even in a focused and emergent field such as robotics.

      Concurrently, we have got interest from industry in the potential of our technology to provide access to networked robots of varying degrees of complexity over the internet, for the purpose of machine learning. The system developed as a result of the SBIR program is ideal for such machine learning efforts, since it provides highly complex robotic hardware to companies interested in AI and Machine Learning applications, without needing to invest in the hardware. A hypothetical embodiment of an application could be a group of robots collaboratively learning tasks via algoritms fed to them over the internet. While this represents another exciting opportunity for the prototypes developed during this project, these efforts could eventually lead to our initial goal of democratizing access to state of the art robots, where all educational institutions could have free access to these robots while the platform is commercialized through industry partners. 

     We believe that the NSF SBIR Phase I project has helped us build a unique technology for truly making robotics easier to understand and use for a large population of students, helping them play relevant roles in our robotics centered future.
